tool.name: cd-hit[-est][-2d]
tool.description: Cluster or compare sequence data sets
tool.command:
cd-hit$est.est-select$twod.twod-select -i "$fasta_in" -o rep_seq -c $similarity -n $est.wordsize #if $est.est-select == '-est': $est.strand #if str($est.adv-align.mask) != 'None': -mask $est.adv-align.mask #end if #if $est.adv-align == 'yes': -match $est.adv-align.match -mismatch $est.adv-align.mismatch -gap $est.adv-align.gap -gap-ext $est.adv-align.gapext #end of #else: #if str($est.redtol) != 'None': -t $est.redtol #end if #end if #if $twod.twod-select == '-2d': -i2 "$fasta_in2" #if $twod.advancedtwod.advancedtwod-select == 'yes': #if str($twod.advancedtwod.cutoff_diff_len2) != 'None': -s2 $twod.advancedtwod.cutoff_diff_len2 #end if #if str($twod.advancedtwod.aa_cutoff_diff_len2) != 'None': -S2 $twod.advancedtwod.aa_cutoff_diff_len2 #end if #end if #end if
#if $advanced.settings == 'yes': #if str($advanced.band_width) != 'None': -b $advanced.band_width #end if #if str($advanced.throw_away_len) != 'None': -l $advanced.throw_away_len #end if #if $advanced.align.style == 'local': -G 0 #if str($advanced.align.align_coverage_long) != 'None': -aL $advanced.align.align_coverage_long #end if
#if str($advanced.align.align_coverage_long_control) != 'None': -AL $advanced.align.align_coverage_long_control #end if
#if str($advanced.aling.align_coverage_short) != 'None': -aS $advanced.align.align_coverage_short #end if
#if str($advanced.aling.align_coverage_short_control) != 'None': -AS $advanced.align.align_coverage_short_control #end if
#if str($advanced.align.align_coverage_min) != 'None': -A $advanced.align.aling_coverage_min #end if #end if #if str($advanced.cutoff_diff_len) != 'None': -s $advanced.cutoff_diff_len #end if #if str($advanced.aa_cutoff_diff_len) != 'None': -S $advanced.aa_cutoff_diff_len #end if #if str($advanced.max_unmatched_per_l) != 'None': -uL $advanced.max_unmatched_per_l #end if #if str($advanced.max_unmatched_per_s) != 'None': -uS $advanced.max_unmatched_per_s #end if #if str($advanced.max_unmatched_len) != 'None': -U $advanced.max_unmatched_len #end if #end if $advanced.inram $advanced.accurate #if $print_alnolv.print_alnolv_select == "yes": -p 1 #if str($print_alnovl.desclen) != 'None': -d $print_alnovl.desclen #end if #end if -M 0 -T \${GALAXY_SLOTS:-1}

param.name: cutoff_diff_len2
param.label: Length difference cutoff for other sequences
param.help: by default, seqs in db1 >= seqs in db2 in a same cluster if set to 0.9, seqs in db1 may just >= 90% seqs in db2 (-s2)

param.name: aa_cutoff_diff_len2
param.label: Length difference cutoff in residues for other sequences
param.help: by default, seqs in db1 >= seqs in db2 in a same cluster if set to 60, seqs in db2 may 60aa longer than seqs in db1 (-S2)

param.name: est-select
param.label: Sequence type? For nucleotid the -est variant of cd-hit is called

param.name: wordsize
param.label: Word size
param.help: It is suggested to adjust word size in function of similarity threshold. 5 for threshold in [0.7;1.0] interval, 4 for [0.6;0.7], 3 for [0.5;0.6], 2 for [0.4;0.5] (-n)

param.name: wordsize
param.label: Word size
param.help: It is suggested to adjust word size in function of similarity threshold. 10,11 for threshold in [0.95;1.0] 8,9 for threshold in [0.9;0,95] interval, 7 for [0.88;0.9], 6 for [0.85;0.88], 5 for [0.80;0.85], 4 for [0.75;0.8] (-n)

param.name: mask
param.label: masking letters
param.help: NX, to mask out both 'N' and 'X' (-mask)

param.name: match
param.label: match score
param.help: match score, default 2 (1 for T-U and N-N) (-match)

param.name: mismatch
param.label: mismatch score
param.help: mismatch score, default -2 (-mismatch)

param.name: gap
param.label: gap opening score
param.help: gap opening score, default -6 (-gap)

param.name: gapext
param.label: gap extension score
param.help: gap extension score, default -1 (-gap-ext)

param.name: similarity
param.label: Sequence identity threshold
param.help: global sequence identity: number of identical alignment positions divided by the full length of the shorter sequence(-c)

param.name: style
param.label: use local/global sequence identity
param.help: local sequence identity: number of identical amino alignment positions divided by the length of the alignment.

param.name: align_coverage_long
param.label: Alignment coverage for the longer sequence
param.help: Fraction of the longer sequence that must be covered (-aL)

param.name: align_coverage_long_control
param.label: Alignment coverage control for the longer sequence
param.help: Maximum number of residues uncovered residues of the longer sequence (-AL)

param.name: align_coverage_short
param.label: Alignment coverage for the shorter sequence
param.help: Fraction of the shorter sequence that must be covered (-aS)

param.name: align_coverage_short_control
param.label: Alignment coverage control for the shorter sequence
param.help: Maximum number of residues uncovered residues of the shorter sequence (-AS)

param.name: align_coverage_min
param.label: Minimal alignment coverage control for the both sequences
param.help: Minimum number of residues of both sequences that must be covered (-A)

param.name: cutoff_diff_len
param.label: Length difference cutoff
param.help: If set to 0.9, the shorter sequences need to be at least 90% length of the representative of the cluster (-s)

param.name: aa_cutoff_diff_len
param.label: Length difference cutoff in residues
param.help: If set to 60, the length difference between the shorter sequences and the representative of the cluster can not be bigger than 60 (-S)

param.name: max_unmatched_per_l
param.label: maximum unmatched percentage for the shorter sequence
param.help: if set to 0.1, the unmatched region (excluding leading and tailing gaps) must not be more than 10% of the sequence(-uL)

param.name: max_unmatched_per_s
param.label: maximum unmatched percentage for the shorter sequence
param.help: if set to 0.1, the unmatched region (excluding leading and tailing gaps) must not be more than 10% of the sequence (-uS)

param.name: max_unmatched_len
param.label: maximum unmatched length
param.help: if set to 10, the unmatched region (excluding leading and tailing gaps) must not be more than 10 bases (-U)

param.name: inram
param.label: sequences are stored in RAM
param.help: if false: sequence are stored on hard drive - use for huge data sets

param.name: accurate
param.label: accurate but slow mode
param.help: by cd-hit's default algorithm, a sequence is clustered to the first cluster that meet the threshold (fast cluster). If set to true, the program will cluster it into the most similar cluster that meet the threshold (accurate but slow mode)

param.name: desclen
param.label: length of description in .clstr file
param.help: if set to 0, it takes the fasta defline and stops at first space (-d)

tool.help:
**What it does**
cd-hit stands for Cluster Database at High Identity with Tolerance. The tool implements four variants: cd-hit, cd-hit-est, cd-hit-2d, and cd-hit-est-2d.
The programs cd-hit (cd-hit-est) takes a fasta format aminoacid (nucleotide) sequence database as input and produces a set of 'non-redundant' (nr) representative sequences as output. In addition cd-hit outputs a cluster file, documenting the members of the sequence clusters for each nr sequence representative. The idea is to reduce the overall size of the database without removing any sequence information by only removing 'redundant' (or highly similar) sequences. This is why the resulting database is called non-redundant (nr). Essentially, cd-hit (cd-hit-est) produces a set of closely related protein (nucleotide sequence) families from a given fasta sequence database.
The programs cd-hit-2d (cd-hit-est-2d) compares 2 aminoacid (nucleotide) sequence datasets (db1, db2) in fasta format. It identifies the sequences in db2 that are similar to db1 at a certain threshold. The output are two files: a fasta file of sequences in db2 that are not similar to db1 and a text file that lists similar sequences between db1 & db2.
.. _CD-HIT: http://www.bioinformatics.org/cd-hit/
------
**Inputs**
cd-hit/cd-hit-2d requires a (two) protein fasta file(s) as input.
cd-hit-est/cd-hit-est-2d requires a (two) nucleotide fasta file(s) as input.
------
**Outputs**
For cd-hit and cd-hit-est:
1. The first output is a fasta file containing representative sequences.
2. The second output is a text file listing the mapping of sequences to the representative sequences:
>Cluster 0 0 2799aa, >PF04998.6|RPOC2_CHLRE/275-3073... * >Cluster 1 0 2214aa, >PF06317.1|Q6Y625_9VIRU/1-2214... at 80% 1 2215aa, >PF06317.1|O09705_9VIRU/1-2215... at 84% 2 2217aa, >PF06317.1|Q6Y630_9VIRU/1-2217... * 3 2216aa, >PF06317.1|Q6GWS6_9VIRU/1-2216... at 84% 4 527aa, >PF06317.1|Q67E14_9VIRU/6-532... at 63% >Cluster 2 0 2202aa, >PF06317.1|Q6UY61_9VIRU/8-2209... at 60% 1 2208aa, >PF06317.1|Q6IVU4_JUNIN/1-2208... * 2 2207aa, >PF06317.1|Q6IVU0_MACHU/1-2207... at 73% 3 2208aa, >PF06317.1|RRPO_TACV/1-2208... at 69%
For cd-hit-2d and cd-hit-est-2d:
1. The first output is a fasta file of sequences in db2 that are not similar to db1.
2. The second output is a text file that lists similar sequences between db1 & db2
